description: From Middle English sprenkelen, sprynklen, from Middle Dutch sprenkelen, equivalent to spring +‎ -le (frequentative suffix). Cognate with Dutch sprenkelen (“to sprinkle”), German Low German sprenkeln (“to sprinkle; dapple”), German sprenkeln (“to sprinkle”).

entries.meaning: A light covering with a sprinkled substance.
examples: He decorated the Christmas card with a sprinkle of glitter.

entries.meaning: An aspersorium or utensil for sprinkling.
A small hard piece of sugar and starch, or chocolate, used to decorate cakes etc.

verbs.description: sprinkle (third-person singular simple present sprinkles, present participle sprinkling, simple past and past participle sprinkled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (a substance) to fall in fine drops (for a liquid substance) or small pieces (for a solid substance).
examples: The confectioner sprinkled icing sugar over the cakes.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cover (an object) by sprinkling a substance on to it.
examples: The confectioner sprinkled the cakes with icing sugar.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To drip in fine drops, sometimes sporadically.
examples: It sprinkled outside all day long.
It sprinkled very early in the morning.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To baptize by the application of a few drops, or a small quantity, of water; hence, to cleanse; to purify.
examples: having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience
